channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rishi Sunak Wins Contest to be UK’s Next PM and Confront Economic Storm
item.description: After a period of chaos, Mr. Sunak, a Conservative, faces serious political and economic headwinds. He will be the first person of color and first Hindu to be prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, center, outside Conservative Party headquarters in London on Monday.

item.title: Sunak’s Ascent Is a Breakthrough for Diversity, With Privilege
item.description: Rishi Sunak’s ascent to the prime minister’s office is a significant milestone for Britain’s Indian diaspora. But for many, his immense personal wealth has made him less relatable.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating Diwali in northwest London on Monday. As many as 1.5 million people of Indian descent live in England and Wales, making them the largest ethnic group after white Britons.

item.title: How Rich Is Rishi Sunak, Britain’s Incoming Prime Minister?
item.description: Just how rich is the soon-to-be prime minister of Britain?
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:credit: Ian West/PA Image, via Alamy
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak and his wife, Akshata Murty, at a reception in February for the British Asian Trust in London.

item.title: Pelosi, Democrats’ Billion-Dollar Woman, Fights On With Majority Teetering
item.description: The speaker, busy raising millions, is in no mood to contemplate a Democratic defeat in November, much less discuss her legacy.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi has raised $276 million at more than 400 events this election cycle. This month alone, she has visited more than 20 cities.

item.title: Why Detroit Won’t Elect a Black Democrat to Congress
item.description: Shri Thanedar’s primary victory means that for the first time in nearly 70 years, Detroit may not send a Black representative to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: State Representative Shri Thanedar, a 67-year old Indian American multimillionaire, beat eight Black candidates in the Democratic primary for Michigan’s 13th Congressional District.

item.title: Fearing a New Shellacking, Democrats Rush for Economic Message
item.description: In the final stretch before the 2022 midterm elections, some Democrats are pushing for a new message that acknowledges the pain of rising prices.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman and Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Doug Strickland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers at Hunter’s Salvage Grocery in Trenton, Ga. The cost of groceries has increased significantly since last year.

item.title: Prosecutors Pressure Trump Aides to Testify in Documents Case
item.description: The Justice Department’s effort to win the witnesses’ cooperation shows how the investigation stemming from the classified materials found at Mar-a-Lago is entering a new phase.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prosecutors are particularly focused on one aide who could provide insight into former President Donald J. Trump’s intentions as he parried the Justice Department’s attempts to reclaim documents from him.

item.title: Their America Is Vanishing. Like Trump, They Insist They Were Cheated.
item.description: The white majority is fading, the economy is changing and there’s a pervasive sense of loss in districts where Republicans fought the outcome of the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Michael H. Keller and David D. Kirkpatrick
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Richmond, Texas.

item.title: Justice Thomas Briefly Shields Graham From Georgia Elections Inquiry Subpoena
item.description: The justice’s order was an “administrative stay” that will almost certainly not be the Supreme Court’s last word on the matter.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The decision temporarily shielded Senator Lindsey Graham from having to answer questions in front of a Georgia grand jury.

item.title: Alito Assured Ted Kennedy in 2005 of Respect for Roe v. Wade, Diary Says
item.description: In the senator’s recollection, the Supreme Court justice who wrote the opinion overturning the abortion ruling tried to show Mr. Kennedy that he was not a threat to Roe.
item.dc:creator: John A. Farrell
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/ The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, questioned Samuel A. Alito Jr. during his Supreme Court confirmation hearing in 2006.

item.title: Where Russians Retreated, Ukrainians Find Devastation
item.description: Returning to liberated towns, Ukrainians find destruction on a staggering scale, vital services cut, and the prospect of a lethal winter ahead.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

item.title: Western Officials Warn Russia Could Use a Dirty Bomb as a Pretext
item.description: Top officials from the United States, Britain and France cautioned that there was no change in Russia’s nuclear posture and that they believed no decision had been made to use a tactical nuclear weapon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a Ukrainian drone unit hunting for Russian positions to target. With Ukraine continuing to make gains against Russian forces, there has been little immediate gain for the Kremlin.

item.title: Russian Officials Flee Kherson as Russian Troops Dig In for a Battle
item.description: In Kherson, the first Ukrainian city to fall after the Russian invasion, occupation forces appear to be preparing to fight advancing Ukrainian troops.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a heavily shelled schoolyard, Ukrainian troops searched for explosives and booby traps, in the Kherson region on Monday.

item.title: Brittney Griner Doesn’t Expect ‘Miracles to Happen’ With Her Appeal
item.description: If the appeals court won’t overrule Ms. Griner’s verdict, it will come into force and she will be sent to a penal colony.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kirill Kudryavtsev
item.media:description: Brittney Griner in Khimki, outside Moscow, in August. She has been sentenced to nine years after Russian officials said she was carrying hashish oil in her luggage.

item.title: Kanye West, Dropped by CAA, Makes Adidas and Corporate Partners Squirm
item.description: The antisemitic outbursts and provocations by the artist now known as Ye have raised questions about how much offensive behavior companies are willing to tolerate from a proven moneymaker.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario, Vanessa Friedman, Jessica Testa and Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kanye West, now known as Ye, in New York last month. After several weeks of outbursts on social media and in interviews, several brands and designers have been distancing themselves from him.

item.title: After Hollywood’s #MeToo Reckoning, a Fear It Was Only Short-Lived
item.description: The movement led to increased diversity and representation in the entertainment industry, but now there is worry that executives have turned their attention elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
item.media:credit: Mary Haasdyk

item.title: Opening Statements Begin in Harvey Weinstein’s Los Angeles Trial
item.description: The former Hollywood producer was convicted in New York in 2020 of rape and criminal sexual assault. He faces 11 separate charges in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Lauren Herstik
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Etienne Laurent
item.media:description: Harvey Weinstein, once one of the most influential producers in Hollywood, in a Los Angeles court earlier this month.

item.title: Leslie Jordan, ‘Will & Grace’ Actor and Instagram Star, Dies at 67
item.description: Shows like “Will & Grace” made him a familiar face, then the pandemic brought new fame. He was killed in a car crash in Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:credit: Chris Haston/NBC Universal via Getty Images
item.media:description: Leslie Jordan, center, in a scene from the hit sitcom “Will & Grace.” He won an Emmy as the tart-tongued socialite Beverley Leslie.

item.title: Why the Family of an NFL Player Is Suing a Real Housewives Star
item.description: She lost her only son, a former N.F.L. player. A settlement would have provided some solace, but even that was taken away.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas and Morgan Lieberman
item.media:description: Photos of Chuck Osborne, who played football at the University of Arizona and in the N.F.L., are displayed in the home of his mother, Kathleen Bajgrowicz.

item.title: Why Dine at the RH Restaurant, From the Brand Formerly Called Restoration Hardware?
item.description: The furnishings store has moved into the hospitality business — but the food may not be the point.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The home-design company RH has opened 15 restaurants across the United States and Canada since 2015.

item.title: Crime: Red Delusions About Purple Reality
item.description: No, Democrats aren’t responsible for rising crime.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Matt Rourke/Associated Press

item.title: We May Have Only a Few Months to Prevent the Next Pandemic
item.description: The window to act is closing fast.
item.dc:creator: Craig Spencer

item.title: This Wasn’t the Vibe Shift Democrats Had in Mind
item.description: Republicans are threatening to peak at exactly the wrong moment for Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kari Lake appears to be on a roll in Arizona.

item.title: Biden and Trump Share One Thing
item.description: They may be the two weakest presidents since before the progressive era.
item.dc:creator: Yuval Levin
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Photographs by Glowimages, maximkabb, and wilatlak villette via Getty

item.title: The Way Los Angeles Is Trying to Solve Homelessness Is ‘Absolutely Insane’
item.description: Developing affordable housing projects shouldn’t make a miserable existence for those who’ve devoted their lives to it.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeremiah Dean, near an encampment in the parking lot where the Venice Dell Community project may be built in Los Angeles. Mr. Dean is homeless and has been living in a tent in the parking lot for more than three months.

item.title: In Praise of the Humble Rule of Thumb
item.description: Fast, frugal and robust, rules of thumb are decision-making powerhouses.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.category: How to Stay Smart in a Smart World: Why Human Intelligence Still Beats Algorithms (Book)
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: Why OPEC Is Cutting Oil Production (and Why There’s Not Much the U.S. Can Do About It)
item.description: Washington sees OPEC Plus’s decision to cut oil production as support for Russia, but Saudi Arabia had legitimate economic reasons for pushing it.
item.dc:creator: Ellen R. Wald
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:credit: Ahmed Jadallah/Reuters
item.media:description: On Oct. 5, a group of oil producers led by Saudi Arabia decided to cut oil production quotas by two million barrels per day starting in November.

item.title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: New Conservative Party leader and incoming prime minister Rishi Sunak.

item.title: Generative A.I. Is Here. Who Should Control It?
item.description: Emad Mostaque, the founder of Stability AI, says his Stable Diffusion image generator is the key to unlocking creativity. His critics say it’s a potential threat.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Paula Szuchman, Corey Schreppel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Elisheba Ittoop
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Affordable Oysters and More Reader Requests
item.description: Looking for the best happy hour deals with quality food? We have recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Shukette in Chelsea, the Middle Eastern menu’s selection of oven-fired breads, richly spiced vegetables and seafood, and dips lends itself handsomely to group dining.

item.title: Do You Have Messy Handwriting? We Want to See It.
item.description: Is your penmanship a mess? Can you often not read your own handwriting? Share something you wrote and later found hard to decipher.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Paoletto
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Teen and Woman Killed in Shooting at St. Louis High School
item.description: The gunman, who was identified as a former student, also died after a shootout with the police at Central Visual and Performing Arts High School, the authorities said. At least seven other people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Fisher, Remy Tumin, Johnny Diaz and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: David Carson/St. Louis Post-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Students standing in a parking lot near Central Visual & Performing Arts High School after a reported shooting at the school in St. Louis, Mo.

item.title: Hasidic School to Pay $8 Million After Admitting to Widespread Fraud
item.description: The Central United Talmudical Academy, which operates the largest all-boys yeshiva in New York State, acknowledged illegally diverting money from federal food aid and other programs.
item.dc:creator: Brian M. Rosenthal and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The operators of the Central United Talmudical Academy in Brooklyn admitted in federal court to diverting government money in a wide-ranging fraud.

item.title: Justice Dept. Charges 2 Chinese Citizens With Spying for Huawei
item.description: Huawei has been a persistent target of the United States government since the administration of President Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and David McCabe
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Justice Department indictment charged Gouchun He and Zheng Wang with paying bribes to an official they believed to be involved in the department’s probe into Huawei.

item.title: Math Scores Fell in Nearly Every State, and Reading Dipped on National Exam
item.description: The results, from what is known as the nation’s report card, offer the most definitive picture yet of the pandemic’s devastating impact on students.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Not a single state was able to improve test scores for math.

item.title: Home Remedies for Cold and Flu Symptoms
item.description: Here’s what we know about some of the most popular remedies that show at least a little promise.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Molly Matalon for The New York Times

item.title: Why Does Alcohol Mess With My Sleep?
item.description: Tips for getting a better night’s rest when your evening plans include drinking.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What Your Dog’s Behavior Means
item.description: Dogs are “really good at reading our emotions,” says one expert. But we’re not so good at reading theirs.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Nicolas Ortega; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: What’s the Best Nondairy Milk Alternative?
item.description: Soy milk, nut milks and other products may offer unique benefits.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What is Microdosing, and Does it Work?
item.description: Scientists are split over whether the benefits some microdosers experience are a placebo effect or something more.
item.dc:creator: Dana G Smith
item.media:credit: River Cousin

item.title: Ryan Condal Was Surprised People Liked ‘House of the Dragon’ So Quickly
item.description: Condal, a showrunner, discussed the challenges of pulling off Season 1 of the first “Game of Thrones” spinoff. “The reward for everybody is that the story from here forward happens in real time,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
